snippet.textDisplay: You guys did a video on the Shadow streaming service a while back. I would highly recommend adding to this even though it's not exactly the same. It's most like Nvidia in reference to all of these services but there is no restrictive licensing (yet). And even with my mediocre internet it works nearly perfectly. The downside is the data use. My Shadow client runs constantly at 60mbs at 1440p. Unless you buy an unlimited package from your ISP, you're likely looking at less than a few hours of playtime a day or you will go over your data cap.

snippet.textDisplay: Now I know you guys probably don’t care much about the little old me’s that watch your videos, but how much data does it take to play these games? Some of us have crappy data limits from satellite internet. For example we have Exede/ViaSat and are paying for 150Gb per month for 3 people. Most of the times we end up using our phones to watch videos because we have faster connection speeds and unlimited data. But it is not ideal to watch everything on a phone screen. So how much data needs to be downloaded to play say 1 or 2 games vs. downloading the entire game and only downloading one a month?
snippet.textOriginal: Now I know you guys probably don’t care much about the little old me’s that watch your videos, but how much data does it take to play these games? snippet.textDisplay: 3:02 So the actual justification is actually about licensing and the EULA. Certain games are for the end user only and there's supposed to be no business involved with the game once it's actually sold. For example, reselling certain games is not allowed. If you look at GeForce Now, what's happening is that an Nvidia designed experience is being set up at a cost on some laggy distanced server. Games already cost x amount and the idea is the developers want to create a standard gaming experience and deliver a specific level of quality and so, if possible, some choose to limit where games can be installed. And lastly, some just simply want to reap all the rewards for themselves so say, if there's another streaming platform they want to use or if they have their own they [can monopolize the revenue on it which is entirely in their right. #themoreyouknow
snippet.textOriginal: 3:02 So the actual justification is actually about licensing and the EULA. Certain games are for the end user only and there's supposed to be no business involved with the game once it's actually sold. For example, reselling certain games is not allowed. snippet.textDisplay:
You guys didn't quite answer the title question...
I think it's hopeless, and it has absolutely everythihg to do with what you didn't test.
The basic problem of game streaming remains the same of Gaikai times, when Playstation now launched, and when nVidia started the GeForce Now thing - infrastructure and marketing/ease of use.
Obviously, LMG has an internet connectivity that less than .something per cent of people probably has. It's not only about the speed too, I'm talking about latency, well configured new routers, modern and well planned Wifi configuration and distribution of access points, plus a ton of other stuff.
It's pretty easy to know the difference. To this day I have problems playing multiplayer games with friends because kids, espouses or parents are watching Netflix or something. Their speed should be enough to support both, but for some reason they just cannot get it to work properly. And let me tell you that some of those friends have bachelors degree in computer engineering or compsci.
That versus buying a box, turning it on, and playing the game.... it reduces the market size to a tiny niche. I mean, that's fine, but it's also exactly the sort of reason why Google has been dropping services. "Not enough interest".
But you know, I've been saying this since the whole game streaming hype train began. The only way I saw Stadia becoming a thing was if they delivered all promisses on launch, particularly that idea of enabling game streamers to play with random spectators with the click of a button. But of course, in keeping with Google traditions, not only they didn't deliver, they already went mute on it, not mentioning it ever anymore, leaving the half assed project abandoned already. They do it everytime, they fail everytime, and they wonder why people don't give them credit for new services.
snippet.textOriginal:
You guys didn't quite answer the title question...
I think it's hopeless, and it has absolutely everythihg to do with what you didn't test.
The basic problem of game streaming remains the same of Gaikai times, when Playstation now launched, and when nVidia started the GeForce Now thing - infrastructure and marketing/ease of use.
Obviously, LMG has an internet connectivity that less than .something per cent of people probably has. It's not only about the speed too, I'm talking about latency, well configured new routers, modern and well planned Wifi configuration and distribution of access points, plus a ton of other stuff.
It's pretty easy to know the difference. To this day I have problems playing multiplayer games with friends because kids, espouses or parents are watching Netflix or something. Their speed should be enough to support both, but for some reason they just cannot get it to work properly. And let me tell you that some of those friends have bachelors degree in computer engineering or compsci.
That versus buying a box, turning it on, and playing the game.... it reduces the market size to a tiny niche. I mean, that's fine, but it's also exactly the sort of reason why Google has been dropping services. "Not enough interest".
But you know, I've been saying this since the whole game streaming hype train began. The only way I saw Stadia becoming a thing was if they delivered all promisses on launch, particularly that idea of enabling game streamers to play with random spectators with the click of a button. But of course, in keeping with Google traditions, not only they didn't deliver, they already went mute on it, not mentioning it ever anymore, leaving the half assed project abandoned already. They do it everytime, they fail everytime, and they wonder why people don't give them credit for new services.

snippet.textDisplay: This is a cool experiment but I don't think it's really going to take off soon, nerds like us who would pay extra for the bandwidth required for this like building rigs and we are super hard to please so it's not for PCMR people, casual people might try it, see it sucks with their non fiber connection and go buy an Xbox at the nearest best buy LAN streaming? That's where it is now, if I can play my PC games on my living room without having to wheel out my rig every time or build a second one I would buy a DEVICE not a subscription, I will not pay a subscription to play MY games on MY hardware over MY network gear

snippet.textDisplay: I write 'cloud' systems automation software and all my user facing software is network loss tolerant. I don't think cloud gaming will ever really compete until network loss tolerant capabilities are offered. In this context network loss tolerant means the ability to handle sudden unexpected sharp dips in network quality as well as complete network loss for some amount of time, typically less than a day, with little to no disruption to the user - assuming the user isn't playing an online synchronous multiplayer game.
snippet.textOriginal: I write 'cloud' systems automation software and all my user facing software is network loss tolerant. I don't think cloud gaming will ever really compete until network loss tolerant capabilities are offered. In this context network loss tolerant means the ability to handle sudden unexpected sharp dips in network quality as well as complete network loss for some amount of time, typically less than a day, with little to no disruption to the user - assuming the user isn't playing an online synchronous multiplayer game.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is just one thing I don't quite get about latency stuff.
I play guitar, and I have an audio interface. I want to be able to use amp simulation and play along to a song on YouTube at the same time. But I can't find a solution to the latency issue. Why can't I play music without terrible latency, but I can play games over the internet with very low latency. How is this possible. Why does an audio interface introduce so much latency.
Even if I use a wireless usb mouse to click somewhere which produces a sound it produce a sound through my wireless headset instantly..
snippet.textOriginal:
There is just one thing I don't quite get about latency stuff.
I play guitar, and I have an audio interface. I want to be able to use amp simulation and play along to a song on YouTube at the same time. But I can't find a solution to the latency issue. Why can't I play music without terrible latency, but I can play games over the internet with very low latency. How is this possible. Why does an audio interface introduce so much latency.
Even if I use a wireless usb mouse to click somewhere which produces a sound it produce a sound through my wireless headset instantly..

snippet.textDisplay: I've played all and GeForce Now ran best for me. I'm in a pretty rural area but I do have a decent fiber connection. I played all via WiFi right next to my AC router. It's only 50 Mbps but the ping is excellent. PS Now was decent. It was definitely playable. xCloud and Stadia (granted Stadia was also in beta when I tried it) was unplayable. I tried Gears 5 and I would overshoot every turn due to the latency. Assassin's Creed Odyssey on Stadia's beta would drop quality to the point that I couldn't see what was going on and would freeze for a second or so at a time and I literally live 50 miles from a data center. GeForce Now seemingly had the lowest latency and quality was spot on.
snippet.textOriginal: I've played all and GeForce Now ran best for me. I'm in a pretty rural area but I do have a decent fiber connection. I played all via WiFi right next to my AC router. It's only 50 Mbps but the ping is excellent. PS Now was decent. It was definitely playable. xCloud and Stadia (granted Stadia was also in beta when I tried it) was unplayable. I tried Gears 5 and I would overshoot every turn due to the latency. Assassin's Creed Odyssey on Stadia's beta would drop quality to the point that I couldn't see what was going on and would freeze for a second or so at a time and I literally live 50 miles from a data center. GeForce Now seemingly had the lowest latency and quality was spot on.

snippet.textDisplay: Something not mentioned about Xcloud in this video: If you own an Xbox you can use it as your own personal Xcloud server for free. Every game you have installed on that Xbox is playable over the service,  which means every game in your Xbox library, and every game for sale on Xbox live is potentially available on Xcloud at no additional cost.
snippet.textOriginal: Something not mentioned about Xcloud in this video: If you own an Xbox you can use it as your own personal Xcloud server for free.
